isis.stitle: TSI 94-08-02 - Data Link Driven Speedometer and Tachometer

subjectgroup.subject: Data Link Driven Speedometer and Tachometer

lev1.title: GENERAL
lev1.para: Navistar has changed the way the speedometer and tachometer are wired for all 1994 vehicles equipped with electronic engines. Prior to 1994, the tachometer was fed from the flywheel sensor and the speedometer was fed from one of the outputs of a dual sensor on the rear of the transmission. With 1994 electronic engines, the speedometer and tachometer are fed from the engine Electronic Control Module (ECM) by way of the SAE J1708 data link. A single speed sensor at the rear of the transmission now feeds the ECM and a flywheel sensor is no longer required. The ECM reads its own speedometer and tachometer data, calibrates the input frequency and transmits the information, via the data link, to the speedometer and tachometer gauges.

Field calibration of the speedometer and tachometer is now done in the ECM and not at the cluster. The cluster is merely programmed to accept speedometer and tachometer information from the data link and the only calibration required is setting the dip switches for miles or kilometers.

item.para: Speedometers and tachometers are used in the data link mode for all electronic Caterpillar, Cummins and Detroit engines after January 1, 1994.
Changing tire size or axle ratio in the field will require reprogramming the engine ECM and not the cluster.
Heavy duty vehicles WITHOUT electronically controlled engines are programmed, as before, to operate from standard sensor inputs.
EXAMPLE of dip switch setting for heavy duty vehicle speedometer and tachometer to operate in the data link mode:

verbatim.line: # - Bit 9 of Tach: not used, set to a 0
* - Bit 10 of Tach: Odometer Miles/kilo Switch

lev1.title: MEDIUM DUTY VEHICLES
lev1.para: ECM driven speedometer and tachometer also apply to medium duty vehicles equipped with the NAVISTAR T 444E V-8 electronic engine.

item.para: T 444E electronic engines use buffered speedometer and tachometer signals from the Vehicle Personality Module (VPM). These signals are calibrated to 12 pulses/rev for the tachometer and 30000 pulses per mile for the speedometer.
The dip switch settings for the T 444E electronic engine are also predefined settings. Changes in tire size or axle ratio will require reprogramming the engine ECM.
Medium duty vehicles WITHOUT electronic engines are programmed, as before, to operate from standard sensor outputs.
EXAMPLE of dip switch setting for medium duty vehicle speedometer and tachometer, with T 444E electronic engine, to operate in the data link mode.

verbatim.line: * - Bit 3 of DIP Switch 2: 2 spd. axle ratio 1 = 1.39, 0 = 1.36
# - Bit 7 of DIP Switch 2: Tachometer Scale; always 0 for 3500 RPM
@ - Bit 8 of DIP Switch 2: Odometer switch; 1 = Kilometers, 0 = Miles
